dcterms:title: Assessing the exposure to the UV filter DHHB in urine samples from the German Environmental Specimen Bank (2000â€“2021): Evaluating the impact of a potential impurity of di-n-hexyl phthalate in DHHB
dcterms:abstract: Human biomonitoring (HBM) has become a crucial tool for assessing exposure to emerging chemicals. We analyzed 520 24-h urine samples from the German Environmental Specimen Bank (ESB), collected between 2000 and 2021, for exposure to diethylamino hydroxybenzoyl hexyl benzoate (DHHB), a UV filter increasingly used in sunscreen. The major metabolites were examined: 3-(4-carboxybutyl)oxy-2-hydroxybenzophenone (cBHB), 3-(4-hexylcarboxyl)oxy-2-hydroxybenzophenone (hBHB), and 2-(4-ethylhexyl)oxy-6-hydroxybenzophenone (DHEHP). While BHB and HHEHP were still undetected in 2000, the concentrations of cBHB increased slowly up to 2012, and increased more rapidly afterwards, until 2021.

fabio:hasPublicationVenue.schema:name: International Journal of Hygiene and Environmental Health

fabio:hasPart.dcterms:title: Introduction
fabio:hasPart.fabio:hasContent: Diethylamino hydroxybenzoyl hexyl benzoate (DHHB) known as a UV filter is increasingly incorporated in sunscreens. However, recent research has suggested potential issues with impurities impacting safety.

fabio:hasPart.dcterms:title: Materials and Methods
fabio:hasPart.fabio:hasContent: Human urine samples were obtained from the German Environmental Specimen Bank. Samples were analyzed for DHHB and its metabolites using LC-MS/MS.

fabio:hasPart.dcterms:title: Results
fabio:hasPart.fabio:hasContent: The analysis showed a significant increase in DHHB metabolites over the years, with a notable rise beginning after 2012.

fabio:hasPart.dcterms:title: Discussion
fabio:hasPart.fabio:hasContent: The increasing trend of DHHB exposure indicates potential environmental and health implications, necessitating further study into long-term effects.

fabio:hasPart.dcterms:title: Conclusion
fabio:hasPart.fabio:hasContent: The study highlights the growing exposure to DHHB and its metabolites, suggesting that regulatory measures might be necessary to address these emerging concerns.

cito:cites.dcterms:title: Environmental pathways and human exposure to UV filters
Impacts of UV filter exposure on human health
